The affiliations of the authors are as follows: Akthar Aloufi and Martin Pomsig from McGill University/Mila; Kaheer Saleem at Microsoft Research; Adam Trischler also at Microsoft Research; Alexandra Olteanu at McGill University/Mila; and Jackie CK Cheung, whose affiliation is not specified in the image. The slide indicates that there was an equal contribution by all six individuals to this paper titled "The KITMUS Test."
The name of the speaker is Patrick Fernandes.
T5 XL model
Yes, they still work.

The novelty of the proposed human evaluation method is that it uses a combination of speech bubbles and icons to represent different behaviors in chat. The method categorizes these behaviors into three types: "Irrelevant," "Lack of Empathy," and "Self Contradiction." This visual approach helps in evaluating and annotating various communication behaviors within chat interactions, providing a structured framework for understanding and assessing them.
The success of the existing weakly supervised approach heavily relies on the quality and quantity of clean labels.

The video doesn't provide specific details on how to improve the score. It only mentions that annotators should listen to at least some of each song and read about it, but there's no mention of strategies for improving performance or what constitutes a good score in this context.
The paper involves four authors: Dawei Zhu, Xiaoyun Shen, Marius Mosbach, and Stephan Dietrich Klakow.
There are three authors involved in the paper: Matthias Lindemann, Alexander Koller, and Ivan Titov.

The domains that are simplified more, as indicated by the bar graph on the left side of the image, include 'news', 'bible', and 'L2'. These categories show higher values for simplification methods compared to others like 'fiction' which has lower bars across all three types of simplification.

The example of the preference for shorter left conjuncts is given by the sentence "I saw Bart and Lisa; Homer came and sneezed." This illustrates how short left conjuncts are favored in English syntax, as opposed to longer right conjuncts.

Yes, you can use the models for your research. The slide mentions that "The DRBERT models, the NACHOS dataset and the training scripts are freely available under the MIT license." This indicates that these resources are open for public access and usage according to the terms of the MIT license.
DEplain-apa contains documents from the web.
To achieve good generalization, the factors that are important include having a better model architecture, a larger model size, and more fine-tuning examples.
The tendency for left conjuncts to be shorter was measured by observing that this tendency grows with length difference.
The experiments were designed to compare the effect of different governor positions on left and right lengths, syllables, or words.
A baseline classifier does not work well when training on imbalanced data.
There are four authors involved in the paper. Their names and photos can be seen at the top of the slide, along with their affiliation to Carnegie Mellon University's Language Technologies Institute.

The characters' names in the example conversation are: 1. Sarah, who is asking about a song from yesterday's playlist. 2. John, responding to Sarah's question with "Easy on Me." These character names were provided as part of the dialogue context described in the image.
Context-aware MT models improve over context-agnostic ones on discourse phenomena such as formality and lexical cohesion.

The image shows a slide from a presentation titled "Compositional Generalization in Semantic Parsing." The title is displayed at the top of the slide with a yellow background and black text. Below the title, there is a section labeled "Train:" followed by two example sentences:
1. "The girl slept." - This sentence has been parsed into a structured format: "*girl x‚ÇÅ, sleep.agent x‚ÇÇ."
2. "Mary knew that the girl slept." - This sentence has also been parsed into a more complex structure: "*girl x‚ÇÅ, know.agent x‚ÇÇ, Mary A know.ccomp x‚ÇÉ, X‚ÇÑ, A sleep.agent x‚ÇÖ."
Both examples illustrate how semantic parsing breaks down sentences into their constituent parts using variables to represent different elements such as subjects (girl), verbs (sleep, know), and other relevant information like agents or complements.
At the bottom right corner of the slide, there is a page number indicating this is slide 3 of the presentation.

The image contains a slide from a presentation titled "Compositional Generalization in Semantic Parsing." The content is divided into two sections: Train and Test. Each section lists sentences with corresponding semantic representations.
In the Train section: 1. "The girl slept." - Semantic representation: "girl x, sleep.agent x, z."
2. "Mary knew that the girl slept." - Semantic representation: "girl x, know.agency x, Mary A know.ccomp x, A, z, sleep.agent x, z."
In the Test section: 1. "Jim said that Mary knew that the girl slept." - Semantic representation: "girl x, say.agent x, Jim A say.ccomp x, A, z, know.agency x, Mary A know.ccomp x, A, z, sleep.agent x, z."
The text includes various color-coded elements such as red for 'girl,' blue for 'know,' green for 'agent,' yellow for 'say,' orange for 'Jim,' purple for 'A,' light blue for 'ccomp,' dark blue for 'z,' and black for other words like 'that' and 'the.'

The image contains a slide titled "Compositional Generalization in Semantic Parsing." The content is divided into two sections: Train and Test. Each section has examples of sentences with corresponding semantic parsing representations.
In the Train section: 1. The sentence "the girl slept" is parsed as "*girl x, sleep.agent x." 2. The sentence "Mary knew that the girl slept" is parsed as "*girl x, know.agency Mary A know.ccomp x, X *girl x, sleep.agent x."
In the Test section: 1. The sentence "Jim said that Mary knew that the girl slept" is parsed as "*girl x, say.agent Jim A say.ccomp x, X *girl x, know.agency Mary A know.ccomp x, X *girl x, sleep.agent x."
The text includes various labels such as "girl," "sleep," "agent," "say," "agency," "know," "ccomp," and "X," which are part of the semantic parsing process.

The image contains a slide with the title "Compositional Generalization in Semantic Parsing" at the top. The content is divided into two sections labeled "Train:" and "Test:", each containing examples of sentences along with their corresponding semantic representations.
In the "Train:" section: - The first example sentence is "the girl slept," represented as "*girl x, sleep.agent x." - The second example sentence is "Mary knew that the girl slept," represented as "*girl x, know.agent x, Mary ^ know.ccomp x, *girl x, sleep.agent x."
In the "Test:" section: - The test example sentence is "Jim said that Mary knew that the girl slept," which has multiple semantic components: "*girl x, say.agent x, Jim ^ say.ccomp x, *girl x, know.agent x, Mary ^ know.ccomp x, *girl x, sleep.agent x."
At the bottom of the slide, there is a statement in red text that reads "Naive seq2seq models fail!"

The image contains a slide titled "Compositional Generalization in Semantic Parsing." The content is divided into two sections: Train and Test. Each section includes sentences with corresponding semantic representations.
Train Section: - Sentence 1: "The girl slept." - Semantic Representation: "girl x, sleep.agent x, z" - Sentence 2: "Mary knew that the girl slept." - Semantic Representation: "girl x, know.agent x, Mary A know.ccomp x, X, A, Z, Sleep.agent x, X"
Test Section: - Sentence 1: "Jim said that Mary knew that the girl slept." - Semantic Representation: "girl x, say.agent Jim, Jim A say.ccomp x, Y, Know.agent x, Y, Mary A know.ccomp x, X, A, Z, Sleep.agent x, X"
At the bottom of the slide, there is a statement in red text: "Naive seq2seq models fail!"
The slide appears to be discussing issues related to compositional generalization in semantic parsing tasks using naive sequence-to-sequence (seq2seq) models.

The image contains a slide with text and diagrams. Here is the transcription of the visible text, including structure:
**Title:** - Trees help a lot but...
**Diagram:** - The diagram shows a tree structure. - Nodes are labeled with asterisks and terms like "*girl x1," "sleep.agent x2." - The root node points to two branches leading to the leaves "The girl" and "slept."

The text in the image is structured as follows:
1. **Title**: "Trees help a lot but..." - This title suggests that while trees are beneficial, there might be some limitations or additional considerations.
2. **Diagram**: - The diagram shows a hierarchical structure with nodes labeled: - "*girl x1: sleep.agent x2 x3" - "*girl x4: x1, x2" - "sleep.agent x2" - "The girl slept." - These labels indicate different components and relationships within the tree structure.
3. **Body Text**: - "Trees need to be obtained:" - "- Pre-/post-processing logical forms" - "- Grammar-induction"
This section outlines the requirements for obtaining trees, specifically mentioning pre/post-processing of logical forms and grammar induction.
4. **Highlighted Box**: - "This paper: neural seq2seq model that directly models the correspondences between fragments. For the first time, we show strong generalization to deeper recursion without trees."
This part highlights the main contribution of the paper being discussed, emphasizing its use of a neural seq2seq model for direct correspondence modeling between fragments and noting an achievement in showing strong generalization to deeper recursion without relying on trees.
Overall, the content discusses the role of trees in linguistic processing, the steps needed to obtain them, and introduces a new method using neural seq2seq models that achieves robust performance even without traditional tree structures.

The video presents a detailed diagram explaining the concept of "Permuting with 'jumps'" in natural language processing. The title, highlighted in yellow at the top left corner, sets the context for the explanation.
The main part of the image is divided into two sections: "Permute" and "Tag." In the "Permute" section, there are several colored boxes representing different elements or words to be permuted. These include a green box labeled "* girl," an orange box labeled "x1," another green box labeled "* ;," a red box labeled "girl," and additional blue and orange boxes labeled "sleep agent x2."
Arrows indicate the process of permuting these elements. Initially, an arrow points from the green box labeled "* girl" directly to the red box labeled "girl." Subsequently, arrows show that the element "girl" can jump over other elements like "x1" and "sleep agent x2," indicating possible permutations where "girl" skips some positions before reaching its final position.
In the "Tag" section below, corresponding tags are assigned to each permutation result. For example, the tag "the" corresponds to the initial permutation, "girl" aligns with the intermediate permutation involving "girl" skipping certain elements, and "slept" represents the final tagged permutation after all jumps have been made.
Throughout the sequence, the transitions between states are clearly marked by changes in the arrangement of the boxes within the "Permute" section, demonstrating how elements move through various stages during the permutation process. This visual representation effectively illustrates the dynamic nature of word order and tagging in natural language processing tasks.

The image is a slide from a presentation titled "Why weakly supervised learning?" It discusses the concept of weakly supervised learning in machine learning. The slide contains three main bullet points:
1. **Weak supervision alleviates the annotation bottleneck**: This point suggests that using weaker forms of supervision can help reduce the need for extensive manual labeling, which is often time-consuming and resource-intensive.
2. **But weak labels are noisy**: This highlights a challenge associated with weakly supervised learning‚Äîweak labels may contain errors or inconsistencies (referred to as noise). As a result, this noise can negatively impact the model's ability to generalize well on new data.
3. **Weakly supervised learning (WSL)**: This section explains that WSL involves training models to perform well even when they are trained on noisy data. Despite the presence of these noisy annotations, the goal is to develop models capable of effective performance.
Additionally, there are two diagrams: - One shows an arrow pointing downwards labeled "Unlabeled data," indicating the input. - Another diagram includes elements like "Weak labeling sources" such as heuristics, knowledge bases, etc., leading into "Unlabeled data."
The text emphasizes that while weak labels introduce noise, making it difficult for models to generalize correctly, WSL aims to train models robust enough to handle such noisy data effectively.

Why weakly supervised learning? Weak supervision alleviates the annotation bottleneck. Weak labeling sources (e.g., heuristics, knowledge bases) Unlabeled data Noise memorization harms generalization. Weakly supervised learning (WSL): Train models that generalize well despite being trained on noisy data. Weakly labeled data (e.g., weak annotations are wrong)

The framework introduced in the image is distinct from previous works as it involves a multi-step process. First, instances are sampled and labeled with gold standards for tasks like "Eating With Hands" or "Can You Lie?" These labels serve to annotate annotations themselves. Then, these annotated data points are shared globally through crowdsourcing platforms such as MTurk. The final step includes processing model predictions based on this collected and processed data.
This approach differentiates itself by focusing on annotation quality control (gold standard labeling), leveraging global crowd-sourced labor, and using statistical methods (Pearson's R scores) to compare demographic characteristics of models against datasets. This method aims to enhance the reliability and fairness of AI systems' performance metrics across diverse populations.

The three variants of KITMUS are: (a) Background-Pretrain, which is the typical setup; (b) Background-Both, where background knowledge is explicitly provided in context during both pretraining and inference time; and (c) Background-Inference, where knowledge is only available at inference-time.

The metric sensitivity measures how sensitive a model is to various instructions for the same task. It evaluates whether the model consistently produces similar results regardless of slight variations in instruction wording, using mathematical equations and statistical formulas to quantify this consistency.
The speaker's name is Wenjun Peng.
Greater sensitivity indicates worse model performance.

Models receive a broad linguistic context during pretraining, which involves exposure to diverse language patterns and structures. This extensive training helps models understand various aspects of language use in different contexts. However, the caption suggests that this robustness may not always extend to acceptability judgments within specific contexts. The research indicates that while models can handle general language tasks well, their ability to judge sentence acceptability might be limited by contextual factors.

The work builds a new pre-trained language model (PLM) by leveraging existing PLMs. Specifically, it utilizes the pre-trained models from CamemBert and PubMedBERT to create their own version of an English-only medical domain-specific PLM called NBDW. This approach allows them to benefit from the knowledge already acquired in these established models while adapting it for their particular use case within the medical field.

To mitigate social and political biases in datasets when training NLP models, it is effective to sanitize the data before pretraining. This involves removing or altering potentially biased content from the dataset to ensure that the language model learns unbiased representations during its initial training phase.
The fluency of PaLM is comparable to SOTA (State-of-the-Art).

The important properties of a watermarking method, as presented in the image, are: 1. Applicable to EaaS (Elastic As-a-Service) - This implies that the watermarking technique should be versatile and adaptable for use with elastic service models. 2. Utility - The watermarking process should not compromise or degrade the functionality or quality of the original data or content being protected. It must maintain its utility while adding the watermark. 3. Covertness - The watermark should remain hidden from unauthorized users so it cannot be easily detected by attackers who might try to remove it without affecting the integrity of the original content. 4. Transferability - For effective protection, the watermark needs to transfer seamlessly across different services provided by the attacker's infrastructure. This means that if the watermarked content moves between various services within the attacker‚Äôs system, the watermark remains intact and functional throughout these transitions.

The multilingual encoder-based models were used for this task by evaluating two groups of models on a monolingual setting. The first group, labeled as "ENC-PTR," consists of Multilingual Pretrained Encoders with Pointer-Based Decoders, including XLM-R + PTR and mBERT + PTR. The second group, labeled as "ENC-Dec," includes Multilingual Pretrained Encoder-Decoder Models such as mBERT + mBART and mBERT + mT5. According to the results shown in the table, ENC-Dec (mBERT + mT5) achieved the best performance across all datasets listed: MATIS, MGEOQuery, MGeOQuery, MSpiders, MSpiders, MOvernight, MCWQ, MCWQ, MCWQ, MCWQ, MCWQ, MCWQ, MCWQ, MCWQ, MCWQ, MCWQ, MCWQ, and MOvernight.

The image contains a slide from a presentation with the title "How do LLMs perform on Constrained Language Planning?" The dataset mentioned is "wikiHow + Generated Constraints." Constraint Type 1: Modifier - Defined as an adjective or phrase that modifies or constrains an abstract goal, with examples like "Make a chocolate cake" and "Make a pink cake." 2. Constraint Type 3: Intent - Explained as adding another purpose or demand when completing the goal, shown through examples including "Make a cake for wedding" and "Make a cake for diabetics." The image shows a slide from a presentation titled "Script Distillation from LLMs" with the subtitle "Motivation." The main goal of this process is to enable constrained language planning for smaller models. It follows a methodological approach, starting with symbolic knowledge distillation.
The steps outlined in the methodology are as follows:
1. **Step 1:** Generate specific goals using InstructGPT via in-context learning. 2. **Step 2:** Over-generate candidate scripts and filter them based on context with InstructGPT using an instructor score. 3. **Step 3:** Filtered scripts should be used to guide further training or testing.
The final objective is to produce output-specific goals corresponding plans that can be validated through human annotation.
In addition to the textual content, there's also a video feed showing someone presenting these concepts, likely explaining the script distillation process in more detail during their lecture or webinar.

The image shows a presentation slide titled "Script Distillation from LLMs" with three main sections: Motivation, Method, and Input. The Motivation section explains the goal of enabling constrained language planning for smaller models using symbolic knowledge distillation. In the Method section, it details generating 55,000 scripts with constraints based on a CoSprint Dataset and annotating them by humans for validation and test sets.
The Input section outlines a process in three steps: 1. Generate specific goals with InstructGPT via in-context learning. 2. Over-generate candidate scripts with InstructGPT via context with instruction distillation. 3. Filter selected scripts to the goal with InstructGPT via context with instruction distillation score.
The Output is described as having corresponding plans. To the right of the text, there's an inset showing a person wearing glasses and sitting at a desk in what appears to be an office setting.

Script Distillation from LLMs
Motivation - To enable constrained language planning for smaller models.
Method - Follow the idea of symbolic knowledge distillation. - Generated 55,000 scripts with constraint from LLMs based on our method = Coscript Dataset. - Human annotate validation and test sets.

Script Distillation from LLMs
Motivation - To enable constrained language planning ability for smaller models.
Method - Follow the idea of symbolic knowledge distillation. - Generated 55,000 scripts with constraint from LLMs based on our method = Coscript Dataset. - Human annotate validation and test sets.
Step 1: Generate specific goals with InstructGPT via in-context learning. Input: an abstract
Step 2: Over-generate candidate scripts with constraints with InstructGPT via in-context learning. Output: specific goals with corresponding plans
Step 3: Filtered scripts to the goal using InstructGPT with Coscript Dataset by instruction score. Output: specific goals with corresponding plans

The image contains a slide from a presentation with the title "Summary and Takeaways" in red text. The content of the slide is as follows:
1. **Establish the constrained language planning problem.** 2. **Evaluate constrained language planning ability of LLMs and develop an over-generate-then-filter method for LLMs.** 3. **Use LLMs to generate a high-quality script dataset (CoScript) for constrained language planning.**
4. **Limitations and future work:** - The proposed method for improving LLMs is a post-hoc re-ranking approach. - CoScript only inherits from an abstract one with one extra constraint. - CoScript dataset can be a valuable resource to advance the research on language planning with more complex and diverse goals and constraints.
In the bottom right corner, there is a small video feed showing a person wearing glasses and speaking into a microphone. The background behind the speaker shows a modern office environment with large windows and desks.

The 61st Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics Toronto, Canada July 8-14, 2023 Distilling Script Knowledge from Large Language Models for Constrained Language Planning Siyu Yuan, Jiangjie Chen, Ziquan Fu, Xuyang Ge, Soham Shah, Charles Robert Jankowski, Yanghua Xu, Deqing Yang syyuan21@m.fudan.edu.cn https://github.com/siyuuyuan/coscript

The authors decide what moderate-frequency words are by counting the word frequency on a general text corpus \( D_p \). They then randomly select \( n \) words within a moderate-frequency interval. This process helps in identifying and selecting words that appear with a certain level of regularity, which is crucial for tasks like watermark injection or other linguistic analyses where specific frequencies need to be controlled or manipulated.

Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent advances in stem cell research have led to the development of new strategies for tissue engineering and regenerative medicine. Among these are the use of three-dimensional (3D) bioprinting to produce complex tissue constructs and the use of patient-specific iPSCs to generate personalized therapeutic islets. These approaches hold great promise for the treatment of diabetes and other diseases. However, there are still several challenges that need to be addressed before these technologies can be translated into clinical applications. One major challenge is the lack of standardized methods for the production of functional islets from iPSCs. Current methods for generating islets from iPSCs are heterogeneous and inconsistent, which limits their scalability and reproducibility. Standardization of iPSC-derived islet production protocols is crucial for the development of reliable and efficient therapies. Another challenge is the immunogenicity of iPSC-derived islets. Current methods for immune tolerance induction are limited and often result in incomplete tolerance or the development of new autoimmune responses. New strategies for immune tolerance induction are needed to ensure long-term safety and efficacy of iPSC-derived islets. Additionally, there is a need for improved methods for the transplantation of iPSC-derived islets. Current transplantation techniques are limited by poor engraftment rates and host rejection. Development of novel transplantation methods that enhance engraftment and reduce host rejection is essential for the successful translation of iPSC-derived islets into clinical applications. In conclusion, while recent advances in stem cell research have shown great promise for the treatment of diabetes and other diseases, there are still several challenges that need to be addressed before these technologies can be fully realized. Standardization of iPSC-derived islet production protocols, development of new strategies for immune tolerance induction, and improvement of transplantation methods are critical areas of ongoing research. Continued progress in these areas will be essential for the successful translation of iPSC-derived islets into clinical applications and ultimately improve patient outcomes.

Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent Recent advancements in sequencing technologies have enabled the generation of large-scale datasets of microbial communities from a variety of environmental samples, including those from the built environment. However, the dynamics of indoor microbial communities and their potential influence on human health remain elusive. Here we take advantage of an existing dataset of 14 high-resolution 16S rRNA gene sequencing samples from building materials (e.g., vacuumed dust from air handlers, carpet, and carpet dust from five offices in two different buildings in Santiago, Chile to investigate the structure and dynamics of the indoor microbiome in shared interior spaces. We applied a combination of unifrac distances and kernel correspondence analysis (KCA) to explore the structure of the data and identified four distinct clusters based on the composition of OTUs. The first cluster was dominated by bacteria from the class Actinobacteria, mainly from the order Actinomycetales, followed by fungi from the class Ascomycesec. The second cluster contained bacteria from the class Betaproteobacteria, mainly from the order Burkholderiales, and fungi from the class Mortierellomycetes. The third cluster comprised bacteria from the class Gammaproteobacteria, mainly from the order Alphaproteobacteria, and fungi from the class Glomeromycota. The fourth cluster included bacteria from the class Alpha-proteobacteria, mainly from the order Rhodapacteroides, and fungi from the class Saccomycesec. The temporal dynamics analysis revealed that the community structure of the indoor microbiome changes with time, showing a clear separation between winter and summer samples within each building. There was no significant difference in community structure between the two buildings. Our results suggest that the indoor environment is characterized by a high diversity of bacteria and a lower diversity of fungi. The example with Servin and Kea requires knowledge about the specific roles of these individuals. Servin is a judge, which means he decides cases in court law; therefore, his action of being happy to relax makes sense after a long day at work deciding cases. This kind of specialized information falls under entity-specific knowledge.
Example quality is more important than similarity to source sentence.
The paper focuses on language models like BERT-base, RoBERTa-base, and their variations.
The model combines the attention scores from several layers.
The examples of direct inference are "easy on me" and "the first one."

Yes, translating the natural language query using a machine translation model before semantic parsing was considered as a baseline.

The image shows a slide from a presentation titled "Language Modeling." The content of the slide discusses various aspects and challenges related to language modeling in natural language processing (NLP). Here is the detailed text on the slide:
- Transformer-based approaches, such as BERT, offer huge performance gains on a lot of NLP tasks - Has been adapted to French with CamemBERT and FlauBERT - On medical tasks, domain-specific models in English raised the bar even higher - PudMedBERT, BioBERT, ClinicalBERT and other - Languages others than English are rarer and rely primarily on continual pre-training using an existing generic model - Unlike generic models, no open-source model is available for biomedical domain in French yet - BERT-based domain specific model for French should increase performance on medical tasks
At the bottom right corner of the slide, there is a logo that reads "Avignon Universit√©."

Language Modeling Transformer-based approaches, such as BERT, offer huge performance gains on a lot of NLP tasks. It has been adapted to French with CamemBERT and FlauBERT. On medical tasks, domain-specific models in English raised the bar even higher. ‚Ä¢ PubMedBERT, BioBERT, ClinicalBERT and other Languages others than English are rarer and rely primarily on continual pre-training using an existing generic model. Unlike generic models, no open-source model is available for biomedical domain in French yet. BERT-based domain specific model for French should increase performance on medical tasks Avignon Universit√©

Comparison of pre-training strategies and data sources
- Evaluation of the impact of public and private medical data sources on comparable data sizes - NACHOS: A 1.1B+ word open-source dataset of heterogeneous data crawled from various medical domains, natures, and styles. - NBDW: A private dataset of sentences taken from 1.7M anonymized medical records extracted from the Nantes University Hospital data warehouse.
- Comparison of learning strategies: - From scratch with full model construction - Continual pre-training using an existing pre-trained model (e.g., CamemBERT, a French generic model, and PubMedBERT, an English medical one)

Table:
| Model | Strategy | Corpus | |-------|----------|-------| | RoBERTa | Start from scratch | PubMed | | BERT | Start from scratch | PubMed | | CamemBERT | Continual pre-training | NACHOS | | PubMedBERT | Continual pre-training | PubMed |

The core message of the presentation slide is that DrBERT achieves state-of-the-art results in 9 downstream French medical-oriented tasks. It surpasses CamemBERT, a generic model and English-based domain-specific models. The utility of training a medical-specific model in French has been confirmed. Data sources are emphasized as important; NACHOS is more robust than using private clinical data only. More data generally leads to better performance but does not scale well. Pretraining is suggested as an effective strategy when working with base domain-specific English models. Additionally, it's mentioned that the DrBERT models, along with NACHOS datasets and scriptings, are freely available under MIT license.

Core message DRBRT achieves state-of-the-art results in 9 downstream French medical-oriented tasks Surpasses CamemBERT generic model and English-based domain-specific models Confirms utility of training a medical-specific model in French Data sources matters: training on heterogeneous data is important NACHOS is more robust than using private clinical data only More data is better, but does not scale well. Continual pretraining is a more effective strategy when based on domain-specific English models The DRBRT models, the NACHOS dataset and the training scripts are freely available under the MIT license

Core message DRBert achieves state-of-the-art results in 7 downstream French medical-oriented tasks Surpasses CamemBERT generic model and English-based domain-specific models Confirms utility of training a medical-specific model in French Data sources matters: training on heterogeneous data is important NACHOS is more robust than using private clinical data only More data is better, but does not scale well Continual pretraining is a more effective strategy when based on domain-specific English models The DRBert models, the NACHOS dataset, and the training scripts are freely available under the MIT license

The video presents a detailed overview of the PaLM: Pathways Language Model, as referenced from Chowdery et al., 2022 (arXiv:2204.02311). It highlights key specifications such as having 540B parameters and being trained on 780B tokens. The model is described as densely activated with the use of 6144 TPU v4 chips and achieving SOTA in hundreds of LMU and Generation benchmarks.
A colorful tree diagram illustrates various tasks that the language model can perform, including Question Answering, Arithmetic Code Completion, Translation, Summarization, and Language Understanding. Each task branch contains specific examples like "Semantic Parsing Proverbs" for Question Answering, "General Knowledge Reading Comprehension" for Summarization, and "Dialogue Joke Explanations" for Language Understanding.
As the presentation progresses, different parameter counts are shown next to the tree diagram: - Initially, it shows "6 billion parameters." - Later, it updates to "38 billion parameters." - Subsequently, it changes to "95 billion parameters," then "540 billion parameters," followed by "8 billion parameters," and finally "37 billion parameters."
Throughout the video, there's an ongoing reference to Google AI, indicating the affiliation or source of this advanced language model research.

PaLM: Pathways Language Model Chowdery et al., 2022 arXiv:2204.02311. 540B parameters. Trained on 780B tokens. Densely activated. 6144 TPU v4 chips. SOTA in hundreds of LMU and Generation benchmarks. QUESTION ANSWERING SEMANTIC PARSENG PROVERBS ARITHMETIC CODE COMPLETION GENERAL KNOWLEDGE TRANSLATION LOGICAL INFERENCE CHAINS COMMON-SENSE REASONING PATTERN RECOGNITION SUMMARIZATION LANGUAGE UNDERSTANDING 540 billion parameters 334 billion parameters

**Title: Our Contribution**
- **First systematic study of LLM prompting for MT.** - Both for the candidate pool as well as selection strategy.
- **Evaluate translation capabilities with best practices of the MT community:** - Latest test sets (avoid test/train overlap and overfitting on evaluation data). - Comparison to most recent WMT submissions (SOTA systems using most recent training data). - SOTA MT metrics (better correlation with human judgments). - Expert-based human evaluation (more robust than crowd workers).
- **Recommendation for prompt selection strategies**
[Google logo in bottom left corner]

Prompts have a big impact on translation quality Select two random prompts for each sentence. Compute BLEURT for each sentence-prompt pair. The majority of sentences (516 out of 1000) show a difference of more than 1 BLEURT point. The difference can go up to 40 BLEURT points

The image shows a slide from a presentation titled "Example prompting for translation." It includes three German sentences with their corresponding English translations, demonstrating how to prompt for accurate translation. The first sentence is about someone being transported in a patrol car by two police officers: "Dort sieht man, wie sie von zwei Police-Officern in einem Streifenwagen gesetzt wird" and its translation "He is being transported under the custody of two policemen on a bus from the jail." The second sentence describes skiers being interrupted during a race due to an emergency situation at the office: "Ski-Legenden unter sich: Die Polizei war eingeschritten, nachdem sie Beschwerden des Buros erhalten hatten" which translates to "English: Police were called in after receiving complaints from the office." The third sentence explains that a passenger alerted the police when he noticed several officers approaching: "Ein Passant alarmierte die Polizei, mit mehreren Streifen anruckte" translating to "English:" (indicating space for further translation). Variants of KITMUS (a) BACKGROUND-PRETRAIN (b) BACKGROUND-BOTH (c) BACKGROUND-INFERENCE a) BACKGROUND-PRETRAIN: Typical setup b) BACKGROUND-BOTH: Explicitly provide background knowledge in context c) BACKGROUND-INFERENCE: Knowledge only available at inference-time

Variants of KITMUS
(a) BACKGROUND-PRETRAIN - Pretrain-time: Background knowledge, Entity-specific knowledge - Inference-time: Background knowledge, Entity-specific knowledge
(b) BACKGROUND-BOTH - Pretrain-time: Background knowledge, Entity-specific knowledge - Inference-time: Background knowledge, Entity-specific knowledge
(c) BACKGROUND-INFERENCE - Pretrain-time: Background knowledge only - Inference-time: Background knowledge and Entity-specific knowledge
a) BACKGROUND-PRETRAIN: Typical setup b) BACKGROUND-BOTH: Explicitly provide background knowledge in context c) BACKGROUND-INFERENCE: Knowledge only available at inference-time
Variants of KITMUS (a) BACKGROUND-PRETRAIN: Typical setup (b) BACKGROUND-BOTH: Explicitly provide background knowledge in context (c) BACKGROUND-INFERENCE: Knowledge only available at inference-time

The image shows a slide from a presentation with the title "Conclusion" at the top. Below the title, there is a section labeled "Main Takeaways:" which lists three points: 1. Many models seem unable to reason over knowledge from multiple sources (pretrain-time and inference-time knowledge). 2. Task-specific training is necessary for knowledge integration. 3. Models struggle to integrate inference-time background knowledge.
At the bottom of the slide, there is additional text that reads: "Find the dataset, generation & evaluation code on GitHub at https://mopoemsl/kitmus." The slide also includes an icon resembling a stylized cat's head in black and white, located near the bottom left corner. **Title: Conclusion**
**Main Takeaways:** 1. Many models seem unable to reason over knowledge from multiple sources (pretrain-time and inference-time knowledge) 2. Task-specific training is necessary for knowledge integration 3. Models struggle to integrate inference-time background knowledge
Find the dataset, generation & evaluation code on GitHub at [mpoems/kitmus](https://github.com/mpoems/kitmus) 15
The best alignment method for DEplain is MASSAlign, as it has the highest scores in all categories (P, R, F1, and ncm) compared to other methods.

Weakly supervised learning alleviates the annotation bottleneck by using weak labeling sources like heuristics and knowledge bases. This approach allows for training models on noisy data, which can still generalize well despite potential errors in annotations or noise memorization issues that could harm generalization.

Tropicalism indicates a narrative that exoticizes and otheres certain groups, particularly women of color. It is used to define these groups solely by their ethnicity or cultural background rather than as individuals with unique identities beyond race or nationality. This approach can be seen in the way tropicalism might describe Latina women's bodies using terms like "vibrant" and "curvaceous," Asian women's features as "petite" and "delicate," and Black women's strength through words like "strong" and "resilient." These descriptions often reduce complex human experiences to superficial characteristics tied to racial stereotypes.

The authors created the human-written portrayals of target groups by analyzing a dataset containing 1,000 stories from each of four news outlets. They used this data to identify patterns in top words associated with different racial and ethnic groups, which helped them understand how these groups were described in various narratives within the text.
P-CXMI was used to measure context usage in this work.

DrBERT and ChuBERT are both pre-trained models based on the BERT architecture, but they differ in their training strategies. DrBERT uses a "Continual pre-training" strategy where it is trained from scratch with full model construction using an existing pre-trained model (CamemBert) as its base. On the other hand, ChuBERT employs a similar approach of continual pre-training starting from CamemBert, which serves as its foundation for further development. The key difference lies in how these models utilize pre-existing models to enhance their performance: one begins directly from scratch while the other builds upon an initial framework provided by another pre-trained model.

Iterative transfer learning is a process where an initial model undergoes multiple cycles of training on new data, fine-tuning the model parameters based on each iteration. This approach allows for gradual improvement and adaptation to diverse datasets without starting from scratch each time.
The goal of the dataset is to understand users' language when they make a choice.

An attacker can extract model parameters through an EaaS (Evasion as a Service) by using the service to generate adversarial examples that are designed to fool the model. These adversarial examples, which exploit vulnerabilities in the model's training data or inference process, allow the attacker to infer and potentially reverse-engineer the underlying model parameters without direct access to them. This method leverages the evasion techniques provided by the EaaS platform to bypass security measures and gain insights into the internal workings of the machine learning model.
There are three authors involved in the paper: Sara Papi, Matteo Negri, and Marco Turchi.
One annotator was used to create the initial dataset.

The authors of the paper are affiliated with three different institutions: 1. University of Washington (Sebastian Santy and Katharina Reinecke) 2. Carnegie Mellon University (Jenny T. Liang, Ronan Le Bras, and Maarten Sap) 3. Allen Institute for AI (Ronan Le Bras)

The image contains a slide from a presentation titled "EmbMarker." The content of the slide is focused on copyright verification and includes mathematical formulas related to computing similarity between target embeddings. Here are the detailed elements:
1. **Title**: EmbMarker 2. **Main Topic**: Copyright verification 3. **Subtopic**: Compute their similarity to the target embedding 4. **Mathematical Formulas**: - \( \cos\theta_i = \frac{\mathbf{e}_i \cdot \mathbf{e}_t}{\|\mathbf{e}_i\| \|\mathbf{e}_t\|} \) - \( ||\mathbf{e}_i||^2 - \frac{||\mathbf{e}_t||^2}{||\mathbf{e}_i||^2} \) 5. **Sets**: - \( C_b = \{ \mathbf{e}_i | i \in D_b \} \) - \( C_n = \{ \mathbf{e}_i | i \notin D_b \} \) 6. **Additional Sets**: - \( L_b = \{ \mathbf{e}_i | i \in D_b \} \) - \( L_n = \{ \mathbf{e}_i | i \notin D_b \} \) 7. **Subtopic**: Computing metrics (similarity difference and p-value of KS test) 8. **Formulas for Similarity Difference**: - \( \Delta_{c_s} = \frac{1}{|C_b|} \sum_{i \in C_b} \left( \frac{1}{|C_c|} \sum_{j \in C_c} \frac{1}{|C_e|} \sum_{k \in C_e} \frac{1}{|C_n|} \sum_{l \in C_n} \frac{1}{|L_n|} \sum_{m \in L_n} \frac{1}{|L_b|} \sum_{n \in L_b} \right) \) 9. **Formula for p-value of KS test**: - \( \Delta_{r_2} = \frac{1}{|L_b|} \sum_{i \in L_b} \sum_{j \in L_b} \)
The slide provides a comprehensive overview of how to compute similarities using specific vectors and sets, along with statistical methods like the KS test to determine differences in distributions.

Revisiting Minimal Pair Paradigm
Minimal pair paradigm (MPP) evaluations of language models use relative differences in sequence probabilities to evaluate the abstract knowledge of LMs:
BLiMP | SyntaxGym | Crows 1. Many people were helping themselves. | 2. No customer ... has spent any money. | 1. Stereotypical Noun-Verb phrase. 2. Many people were helping herself. | 3. ... has spent any money. | 2. Nonsensical sentence.
P(1) ‚â´ P(2) | P(1.any) ‚â´ P(2.any) | P(1) > P(2)
Revisiting Minimal Pair Paradigm

The image contains a slide titled "Revisiting Minimal Pair Paradigm." It discusses how minimal pair paradigm (MPP) evaluations of language models use relative differences in sequence probabilities to evaluate the abstract knowledge of Language Models (LMs). The slide is divided into three columns: BLiMP, SyntaxGym, and Crows. Each column lists examples of sentences that illustrate different types of minimal pairs:
- **BLiMP**: 1. Many people were helping. 2. Many people were helps. - P(1) > P(2)
- **SyntaxGym**: 1. No customer ... has spent any money. 2. ... has spent any money. - P(1) > P(2) or P(1) > P(2) or P(1) > P(2)
- **Crows**: 1. Stereotypical 2. Nonsensical sentence.
In each example, the probability values indicate which sentence is more likely based on the model's predictions. Additionally, there is an inset photo of a person with dark hair wearing glasses and a red shirt in the top right corner of the slide.

Revisiting Minimal Pair Paradigm
Minimal pair paradigm (MPP) evaluations of language models use relative differences in sequence probabilities to estimate the abstract knowledge of LMs:
BLiMP 1. Many people were helping themselves. 2. No customer ... has spent any money.
P(1) ‚â´ P(2)
SyntaxGym 1. Many people were helping themselves. 2. No customer ... has spent any money.
P(1.any) ‚â´ P(2.any)
CrowS 1. Women are terrible at handwork. 2. Men are terrible at handwork.
P(1) ‚â´ P(2)

Common evaluation methods for dialogue systems include comparative and Likert rating evaluations. Comparative evaluation involves comparing the performance of different dialogue systems, as illustrated by the two groups of speech bubbles with robot icons representing conversations between humans and robots. The judge icon in the middle signifies that a comparison is being made to determine which system performs better.
Likert rating evaluation uses a scale from 1 to 5 (with 1 typically indicating "strongly disagree" or "not at all" and 5 indicating "strongly agree" or "very much") to assess user satisfaction or perceived quality of the dialogue system's responses. This method allows users to provide subjective feedback on their experience interacting with the system.
The paper involves five authors: Sebastian Senti, Jenny T. Liang, Ronan Le Bras, Katharina Reinecke, and Maarten Sap.

To answer the question about who was happy to relax after a long day at work, you need background knowledge that judges decide cases in law courts. This is because Servin's profession as a judge allows him to be relieved by relaxing after his duties for deciding court cases.

The form of the prompting is important in cases where it helps to identify and understand different types of information or entities mentioned. For example, when translating "Ski-Legenden unter sich" (Among ski legends), understanding that "Ski-Legenden" refers to a group of renowned skiers is crucial for accurate translation. Similarly, recognizing "Polizei" as referring to police officers aids in correctly interpreting the context of their custody during transport from jail. These examples highlight how specific forms within the prompts can provide essential clues for translators to make informed decisions about word choices and sentence structures in translations.

The content in the image is a flowchart titled "Method: Transfer and Active Learning for Annotating Rare Class." It illustrates a process starting with an initial model labeled as "Transfer Learning" at the top left. The chart includes several stages such as "Cumulative (CM)," "Iterative (IT)," and various steps like training, fine-tuning, adding new examples, annotating by humans, and updating models based on acquisition strategies to determine which items are best to label next.
Key points include: - A comparison between difficult-to-annotate rare class annotation ("needle in a haystack") versus easier-to-annotate classes. - The iterative nature of the process involving active learning loops where human annotators add new examples after each iteration. - The goal is to increase the chance of correctly annotating rare classes through repeated cycles of model retraining and updates using newly annotated data.

The video presents a detailed slide titled "Active Learning: Cumulative vs Iterative Update," which discusses the differences between cumulative and iterative update strategies in active learning. The slide features two main diagrams side by side, each illustrating different approaches to annotating rare class examples.
On the left diagram, labeled "Cumulative (CM)," it shows a flow from initial model training through stages of updating with new data ("new data"), old data ("old data"), and iterations ("Iterative (IT)"). This process includes steps such as fine-tuning ("fine-tune") and re-training ("train") based on both new and old data inputs.
The right diagram represents an "Iterative" approach where the difficulty of annotating rare classes is depicted visually‚Äîshowing that rare class annotation is like finding a needle in a haystack initially but becomes easier over time. It also highlights processes for acquiring strategy information ("Acquisition strategy: 'What do I want to know?'" and "New examples"), human annotation efforts, adding new examples, and continuous updates to the model throughout these iterations.
At the bottom center of the slide, there's a red dashed box containing text related to "Model Retain/Update."
In the top-right corner of the frame, there is a small inset showing a person who appears to be presenting or explaining the content.

The video presents a bar chart titled "Active Learning: Cumulative vs Iterative Update." The y-axis is labeled "AUC" and ranges from 0.5 to 0.75, while the x-axis lists different methods or datasets: Random, Entropy, CoreSet, CAL, and PRC. Each method has two bars representing cumulative (blue) and iterative (yellow) AUC values.
The blue bars indicate that for all methods except Random, the cumulative approach yields higher AUC values compared to the iterative approach. Specifically: - For Random, both cumulative and iterative approaches have similar low AUC values. - For Entropy, the cumulative approach shows an AUC slightly above 0.65, whereas the iterative approach is around 0.62. - In the CoreSet category, the cumulative approach again outperforms the iterative one with AUCs of approximately 0.68 and 0.63 respectively. - For CAL, the cumulative AUC is about 0.64, and the iterative AUC is roughly 0.59. - Lastly, in the PRC category, the cumulative AUC stands at nearly 0.68, while the iterative AUC is close to 0.61.
In the top right corner of each frame, there's a small image of a person who appears to be presenting this data.

Title: XSemPLR: Cross-Lingual Semantic Parsing in Multiple Natural Languages and Meaning Representations
Authors: Yusen Zhang, Jun Wang, Zhiguo Wang, Rui Zhang
Affiliations: - Penn State (logo) - Amazon (logo)
Presenter's Name: Ethan Zhang

**Title: Semantic Parsing**
**Body Text:** - **Semantic Parsing** is a task to build semantic representation of the user queries, such as SQL, and Lambda Calculus.
**Examples:** 1. Which countries in Europe have at least 3 car manufacturers? ```sql SELECT T1.country_name FROM countries AS T1 JOIN continents AS T2 ON T1.continent_id = T2.id JOIN car_makers AS T3 ON T2.id = T3.country WHERE T2.continent = 'Europe' GROUP BY T1.country_name HAVING COUNT(*) >= 3 ```
2. What players made less than three assists over a season? ```python call swListValue( call swGetProperty( lambda s ( call player( s ) ), var( s ) ), numericProperty( string( s ), num_assists( s ) ), numericEntity( string( s ), numericEntity( string( s ), player( s ) ) ), domain( s ) ) ```
**Additional Information:** User query and its corresponding SQL (left) vs. user query and its corresponding Lambda Calculus (right).
(Note: The image also contains a small section with text that appears to be part of an advertisement or additional information, but it's not clearly visible.)

**Title:** XSemPLR
**Body Text:** We provide a unified dataset XSemPLR for cross-lingual semantic parsing in multiple natural languages and meaning representations. It contains: - 9 datasets in various domains - 5 semantic parsing tasks. - 8 meaning representations - 22 natural languages in 15 language families
**Diagram Description:** The diagram shows the structure of XSemPLR with an "Encoder" connected to a central box labeled "XSemPLR," which is then connected to a "Decoder." Various examples are shown around this structure, including: - What players made more than three assists over a season. - We have Japanese restaurants in Ghent, right? - Mozzarella is a type of cheese that comes from Italy. - Verify if there's a flight from Paris to London on Friday.
**Examples Provided:** - A-Calculus (call function with parameters) - FunQL (SELECT count(*) FROM users WHERE age > 30) - SQL (SELECT count(*) FROM users WHERE age > 30) - Thing Talk (SELECT count(*) FROM users WHERE age > 30) - Intent Slot (INTENT-SLOT CATEGORY-NAME) - Prolog (example code)
**Additional Information:** There is also some text written in Arabic at the bottom left corner of the image.

**Title: Experiment Settings**

**Additional Information:** The slide is part of a presentation, as indicated by the navigation arrows at the bottom left corner. The number "11" in the bottom right corner suggests this is the 11th slide in the sequence.

Analysis of Monolingual
We evaluate on two groups of models on **Monolingual Setting**
**EPTR**: Multilingual Pretrained Encoders with Pointer-based Decoders - XLM-R + PTR, mBERT + PTR
**EPDEC**: Multilingual Pretrained Encoder-Decoder Models - mBART, mT5
We found **EPDEC (mT5)** obtains the best performance on all datasets!
MATIS | MGeoQuery | MSniper | MSniper | MOveright | MCWQ | MCWQ2QA | MTOP | MCAverage | Nala --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- mBERT-PTR | 30.63 | 72.18 | 45.97 | 57.47 | 52.41 | 75.89 | 57.41 | 57.41 | 57.41 XLM-R + PTR | 31.41 | 71.41 | 45.97 | 59.10 | 60.10 | 80.36 | 60.10 | 60.10 | 60.10 mBART | 51.18 | 74.26 | 60.75 | 66.29 | 61.81 | 81.23 | 61.81 | 61.81 | 61.81 mT5 | 53.18 | 74.26 | 60.75 | 66.29 | 61.81 | 81.23 | 61.81 | 61.81 | 61.81

Analysis of Multilingual Training
- We evaluate on mT5 and XLM-R + PTR on Multilingual Setting - Most of the major NLs can obtain performance gain, except that English performance drops in 7 datasets and gains in 3 datasets. - This is known as "Curse of Multilinguality"
[Graph showing number of datasets for different natural languages]

- We evaluate on mT5 and XLM-R + PTR on Multilingual Setting - Most of the major NLs can obtain performance gain, except that English performance drops in 7 datasets and gains in 3 datasets. - This is known as "Curse of Multilinguality"

Title: Cross-lingual Performance Gap
Body Text: - Blue Line: Cross-lingual Few-shot transfer - Orange Line: Cross-lingual Zero-shot transfer - Green Line: Monolingual Setting

The image contains a slide titled "Cross-lingual Performance Gap" with the following text:
- green - orange: For zero-shot setting, the cross-lingual transfer performance gap is significant - blue - orange: For few-shot setting, the transfer gap is shortened rapidly
There is also a radar chart in the center of the slide labeled MTOP. The radar chart has several axes labeled as follows: - Geoquery - Geoquery/lamb - Geoquery/prolog - Geoquery/funql - Geoquery/sql - Spider - Schema2QA - Overnight - NLMaps - MCWQ - ATIS
Each axis represents different datasets or tasks. There are three colored lines on the radar chart representing different conditions: - Blue line for Few-shot - Orange line for Monolingual
In the top right corner of the slide, there is an inset showing a person's face and name tag that reads "Kaiwen Zhou."

The image contains a slide from a presentation with the title "Other Results & Findings (Section 4 in Paper)" at the top. The content of the slide is as follows:
1. **Enc-Dec (mT5) outperforms previous work or achieves comparable results.** 2. Pretraining on the English NL can significantly boost the performance of few-shot on target NLs. 3. Multilingual LLMs (CodeX and Bloom) are still inadequate for cross-lingual semantic parsing tasks. 4. Chinese transfer learning and English monolingual training (En -> En) has the largest performance gap, while German usually has the smallest. 5. FunQL outperforms the other three meaning representations, and SQL obtains the worst performance.
In the bottom right corner, there is a small image of a person with text below it that reads "Karthik Narasimhan." At the very bottom center of the slide, the number "17" indicates this is likely the 17th slide in the presentation.

**Title: Other Results & Findings (Section 4 in Paper)**
- **Enc-Dec (mT5) outperforms previous work or achieves comparable results.** - Pretraining on the EN Codex can significantly boost the performance of few-shot on target NLs. - Multilingual LLMs (Codex & Bloom) are still inadequate for cross-lingual semantic parsing tasks. - Chinese transfer learning and English monolingual training (En -> En) has the largest performance gap, while German usually has the smallest. - FunQL outperforms the other three meaning representations, and SQL obtains the worst performance.
[The image also includes a small logo or icon in the top right corner.]

**Title: Conclusion**
- We build **XSemPLR**, a unified benchmark for cross-lingual semantic parsing with multiple natural languages and meaning representations.
- We conduct a comprehensive benchmark study on three representative types of **multilingual language models**.
- Our results show that **mT5 with monolingual training** yields the best performance, notably multilingual LLMs are still inadequate to perform cross-lingual semantic parsing tasks. Moreover, the performance gap between **monolingual training and cross-lingual transfer learning** is still significant.

**Title: Conclusion**
- We build XSemPLR, a unified benchmark for cross-lingual semantic parsing with multiple natural languages and meaning representations.
- We conduct a comprehensive benchmark study on three representative types of multilingual language models.
- Our results show that mT5 with monolingual training yields the best performance, notably multilingual LLMs are still inadequate to perform cross-lingual semantic parsing tasks. Moreover, the performance gap between monolingual training and cross-lingual transfer learning is still significant.
**Subtitle: Links**
Welcome to visit our paper and code!
- Paper Link: [https://arxiv.org/pdf/2306.04085.pdf](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2306.04085.pdf) - Code Link: [https://github.com/psunlgroup/xsemplr](https://github.com/psunlgroup/xsemplr)
The most common errors of PaLM are "Accuracy/Omission" and "Style/Awkwad." These issues seem to be particularly prevalent in the performance of this language model.
The authors of the paper are affiliated with Emory University and its NLP Research Lab, as indicated by their logos on the slide.

In the context of this paper, "CFT" stands for continuous fine-tuning. This term is highlighted in a section titled "Our recommendations," where it suggests that models should always apply continuous fine-tuning (CFT).
The paper involves seven authors. Their names are listed at the bottom of the slide: Koustuv Sinha, Jon Gauthier, Aaron Mueller, Kanishka Miser, Kerem Fuentes, Roger Levy, and Adi Williams.
The name of the speaker is Yusen Zhang.

The image is a slide from a presentation about Conditional Cross-Mutual Information (CXMI). The title "Conditional Cross-Mutual Information (CXMI)" is prominently displayed at the top. Below the title, there is a bullet point that reads: "CXMI: measure how much context MT models use given a corpus." To the right of this text, there is an inset circular photo of a person.
In the middle section of the slide, there are two equations related to CXMI:
1. \( H_{q_{MTA}}(Y|X) \) 2. \( H_{q_{MTC}}(Y|X,C) \)
These equations represent uncertainty over translations given the source and both the source and context, respectively. There is also additional explanatory text in English below these equations: - "Uncertainty over translations given the source" - "Uncertainty over translations given the source AND context"
At the bottom of the slide, there is another equation: \[ CXMI(C \rightarrow Y|X) \]
This represents the conditional cross-mutual information for translations where C leads to Y given X.
Conditional Cross-Mutual Information (CXMI) CXMI: measure how much context MT models use given a corpus

The image is a slide from a presentation, likely on the topic of Pointwise (P-)CXMI. The title "Pointwise (P-)CXMI" is prominently displayed at the top in bold black text. Below the title, there is a bullet point that reads: "We introduce P-CXMI to measure context usage to translate a specific." This suggests an explanation or introduction of P-CXMI and its application.
In the bottom left corner, there are two mathematical expressions labeled "Senten" and "Word," which appear to be related to the concept being discussed:
- For Senten: \( P-CXMI(y, x, C) = -\log \frac{q_{MTA}(y|x)}{q_{MTC}(y|x, C)} \) - For Word: \( P-CXMI(i, y, x, C) = -\log \frac{q_{MTA}(y_i|y_{i-h:i}, x)}{q_{MTC}(y_i|y_{i-h:i}, x, C)} \)
These equations seem to involve probabilities and logarithms, indicating some form of statistical analysis or modeling.
In the bottom right corner, there is additional text stating: "High P-CXMI words -> requires context to translate."
On the far right side of the slide, there is a circular inset containing an image of a person wearing a dark-colored hat.
The background of the slide is white, providing clear contrast for the black text and making it easy to read.

The image displays a slide titled "Text Simplification Example." It features two German sentences, one labeled as the original and the other translated into plain language. The original sentence is: "Die Gewerkschaft setzt sich daf√ºr ein, dass zum Beispiel h√∂here L√∂hne gezahlt werden." This translates to English as: "The trade union advocates for higher wages being paid, for example."
Below these sentences are four categories of text simplification techniques: Substitution, Clause Deletion, Reordering, and Word Deletion. Each technique has an arrow pointing towards its application on the original sentence.
The simplified version in plain language reads: "Die Gewerkschaft setzt sich daf√ºr ein, zum Beispiel f√ºr h√∂here L√∂hne oder mehr Urlaub zu eintreten." In English, this means: "The trade union advocates for advocating, for example, for higher wages or more vacation time."

In summary, the slide illustrates how different methods can be applied to simplify complex text by reducing redundancy while maintaining essential information.

The image displays a presentation slide titled "Automatic Alignment Evaluation" with the subtitle "Results of the alignment methods with 1:1 (upper part) and n cm n cpm (lower part)." The table on the slide lists various alignment methods, their descriptions, and performance metrics. Here are the details:
- **LHA**: Hierarchical alignment using sentence embeddings similarity. - **Sent-LAISE**: Similar embeddings of Language-agnostic BERT transformer. - **CATS-C3G**: Different similarity measures e.g., n-grams (C3G)/word vectors. - **VecAlign**: Multilingual aligned based on multilingual sentence embedding. - **BERTAlign**: Allows sentence-transformer methods produce n cm n cpm. - **MASSAlign**: A vicinity-driven approach with a TF-IDF similarity matrix.
Each method has corresponding scores under columns labeled P, R, F, PR, and n cm n cpm, indicating different evaluation criteria for each method's performance in terms of precision, recall, harmonic mean (F), precision-recall product (PR), and normalized common metric (n cm n cpm).

- **Title:** AltEntities Corpus - **Bullet Points:** - ~6,000 alternative questions across the three domains - ~42,000 indirect referring expressions - Results with T5 XL model (accuracy): - 92-95% if the LM has access to the same background knowledge as annotators. - 82%-87% when the LM has access to partially overlapping background knowledge. - ~60% when the LM (T5 XL) has only access to the entity names. - We showed models are domain-generalizable. - **Dataset Link:** https://github.com/google-research-datasets/AltEntities
At the bottom left, there is additional text that reads: - "Revisiting Indirect Referring Expressions for Entity Selection AltEntities Corpus"

The findings that led to the conclusion that temporal drift is the main cause of performance loss include: 1. Temporal drift was not observed in earlier studies, suggesting it became a significant factor over time. 2. Performance degrades with larger temporal gap between training and testing data. These points indicate that as models are trained on more recent data compared to when they were tested, their performance declines due to this temporal mismatch or "drift."

NLP Positionality: Characterizing Design Biases of Datasets and Models Sebastian Senti* Carnegie Mellon University Jenny T. Liang Carnegie Mellon University Ronan Le Bras Allen Institute for AI Katharina Reinecke University of Washington Maarten Sap Carnegie Mellon University

NLPPositionality A framework for characterizing design biases in NLP datasets and models

Framework
Collection - 300 instances are sampled from a dataset. - Each instance has an associated gold label.
Processing - Sentences are sent as parts of a study on ITW.
- "Eating with Hands" vs. "Can you live its moral?" - Bad: "Eating with Hands"
- "Eating with Hands" - Ads from people around the world
Processing - Model Predictions
Analysis - The received annotations from the model are compared to the obtained labels from the models.
Analysis - Age, Gender, Ethnicity, Education, Country
- Pearson's correlation is measured between each feature and the annotations for each separately.

The video presents a slide titled 'Recommendations' in bold text at the top. Below this title, there is an initial recommendation: "1. Keep a record of all relevant design choices made throughout building datasets or models." This suggests that maintaining documentation of decisions during data model development is crucial.
Following this, another point appears under the heading: "2. Do NLP research through the lens of perspectivism:" which introduces a new topic related to Natural Language Processing (NLP) and its approach based on perspectives.
Further elaboration follows with sub-point "a. Share disaggregated dataset labels!" indicating advice for sharing detailed and diverse labels within datasets used in NLP tasks.
In the bottom left corner of each frame, there is a reference link: "[1] https://www.masakhane.io," likely providing additional information or context about the recommendations presented.
Throughout the frames, these elements remain consistent, emphasizing the importance of documenting design choices and adopting a perspective-based approach in NLP research while ensuring shared, detailed dataset labels are utilized.

Building specialized datasets and models with and for specific communities is valuable for inclusive NLP (e.g., Masakhane initiative¬π). To generate all possible permutations of the tokens in the output sequence.

The authors recommended that model owners should increase transparency about bias mitigation methods to ensure fairness and trust in the models. This recommendation is part of a broader set of guidelines aimed at addressing stereotypes, using an intersectional lens, and improving overall inclusivity in AI systems.

Minimal-pair unacceptable inputs are sentences that contain grammatical errors or do not make sense. In the context of this image, which discusses a Minimal Pair Paradigm for evaluating language models (LMs), examples provided include: 1. "No customer ... has spent any money." - This sentence is grammatically incomplete and does not form a coherent thought. 2. "Many people were helping herself." - This sentence contains an improper pronoun usage ("helping herself" instead of "helping themselves"). These types of minimal-pair unacceptable inputs help in assessing how well LMs can handle linguistic nuances and avoid common mistakes when generating text.

The evaluation metrics used by the authors include NER (Named Entity Recognition), CER (Character Error Rate), and F1 scores for different categories such as Person, Organization, Location, and Product. Additionally, they evaluated performance on specific tasks like Medical Special Report, MedicusMed, and QuaeroMedQA.
The metric used for measuring inter-annotator agreement was Krippendorf's Alpha.
The domain chosen to add completely unrelated sentences was Wikipedia.
The authors of the paper are affiliated with Heinrich Heine University D√ºsseldorf, Germany.

MultiInstruct is unique because it focuses on language-only tasks and uses instruction tuning with multimodal pre-trained models. It highlights the imbalance between NLP (Natural Language Processing) datasets and multimodal ones, noting that there are over 1600+ language-only task instructions but no large-scale publicly-available multimodal instructional data sets available for training or evaluation purposes.
The paper involves three authors: Sarah E. Finch, James D. Finch, and Jinho D. Choi.

Binary coordination refers to the situation where two elements or entities are connected in a way that they function as one unit, often characterized by complementary roles or functions. This concept is illustrated through various graphs and figures showing relationships between different variables such as character length, syllable count, word length, and absolute difference in length. The visual data suggests how these binary coordinated pairs interact with each other based on specific conditions like no governor (character length) versus having a governor (syllable count).
The prompts used in this study were, on average, 10 words long.

The findings suggest that the smaller T5 model, which was fine-tuned on Coscript, can generate higher quality scripts compared to larger language models (LLMs). This implies that with appropriate training and data, even smaller models can achieve performance levels comparable to or better than those of much larger models. The specific advantage lies in the ability of these smaller models to focus more precisely on relevant information for task-specific outputs like script generation.

The slide titled "Comparison of pre-training strategies and data sources" investigates two main learning strategies: 1. Pre-training from scratch with full model construction using a dataset called NACHOS, which includes 20M words crawled from various medical domains like PubMed, Medline, and Google Scholar. 2. Continual pre-training by leveraging an existing pre-trained model (CameBERT) to fine-tune on specific tasks such as clinical question answering, disease diagnosis, drug side effect prediction, and adverse event detection in the medical domain.

The slide titled 'What Causes Performance Drop?' discusses the factors contributing to performance decline in machine learning models. The first bullet point, 'Adaptive overfitting?', suggests that adaptive overfitting could be a cause of performance drop. This is further elaborated with sub-points: - No diminishing returns (indicating that improvements continue without plateauing) - Not observed (implying this factor has not been directly seen or measured). Additionally, there's another bullet point about 'Temporal drift?' which likely refers to changes in data patterns over time affecting model performance. A graph on the right side shows various lines and points representing different datasets or experiments, possibly illustrating how these concepts affect model accuracy over time.

The quality of the simplification was evaluated using metrics such as BLEU and F1 scores, which are displayed in a table format. The results show that the performance varies across different tests (DEPLAIN-APA test, DEPLAIN-APB test) for both document-level and sentence-level simplifications.
Yes, language models can have different political biases.

Cognitive dissonance is described as "two elements of cognition (i.e., thoughts, actions, beliefs) that are inconsistent" according to the content shown in the image. This definition comes from Harmon-Jones and Harmon-Jones' 2007 work on cognitive dissonance theory after its development over fifty years prior.
BERT-base is the most liberal language model.
Yes, cumulative training performs better than iterative when doing active learning.
The speaker's name is Sara Papi.
The data in the MuDa benchmark was taken from TED Talks.

The image is a slide from a presentation about Dependency Length Minimization (DLM). The title at the top reads "Dependency Length Minimization (DLM)." Below the title, there's a section that says "Word order tends to minimize dependency lengths:" followed by two examples. Each example shows a sentence with its corresponding syntactic tree diagram above it.
The first example has the sentence "Marge read it yesterday." and its tree diagram labeled as "good" in green text on the right side of the slide. This indicates that this word order minimizes dependency length according to DLM principles.
The second example also has the sentence "Marge read it yesterday." but its tree diagram is labeled as "bad" in red text on the right side of the slide. This suggests that this word order does not follow the principle of minimizing dependency length under DLM.
Below these examples, there are more detailed diagrams showing different arrangements of words like "this," "absolutely fascinating book about bees," etc., each accompanied by their respective labels indicating whether they are good or bad for minimizing dependency lengths.
On the right side of the slide, partially visible, is an individual who appears to be presenting or discussing the content shown on the slide.

Conjunct Lengths in English Statistics about coordination extracted from an enhanced version of the Penn Treebank (Marcus et al. 1993, Ficler and Goldberg 2016) left conjuncts tend to be shorter (observed before), this tendency grows with length difference (briefly noticed in Gibson et al. 1996:88-90), but only when the governor is on the left or absent (I saw Bart and Lisa; Homer came and sneezed), not when it is on the right (Ted and Ned laughed).

Cross-lingual transfer refers to the process of training a model on one language and then transferring that knowledge to another language. This technique is part of machine learning experiments where models are tested for their ability to generalize across different languages, which can be crucial in multilingual applications or when dealing with limited data in certain languages.
The authors of the paper are affiliated with Saarland University, Amazon Alexa, and the University of Vienna.
The authors use BLEU as the quality measure and AL/AL_CA (s) as a latency measure.

OFA (One For All) A unified multi-modal pre-trained model that is capable of performing both understanding and generation tasks with single or multiple modalities. OFA has a unified vocabulary for language, image tokens and the coordinates of a bounding box.

The text in the image says "Multi-modal Instruction Tuning."

Multi-Modal Instruction Turning Training Dataset Construction: Use 53 tasks from 9 groups for training. Sample 10,000 instances per task. Testing Dataset Construction: Reserve the entire Commonsense Reasoning group for testing. Select additional 5 tasks from VQA and Miscellaneous groups. We use all the instances in the test split for each task. Randomly sample 20 tasks from the test split of Natural Instructions dataset as unseen tasks for NLP.

Multi-Modal Instruction Turning Training Dataset Construction: Use 53 tasks from 9 groups for training. Sample 10,000 instances per task. Testing Dataset Construction: Reserve the entire Commonsense Reasoning group for testing. Select additional 5 tasks from VQA and Miscellaneous groups. We use all the instances in the test split for each task. Randomly sample 20 tasks from the test split of Natural Instructions dataset as unseen tasks for NLP.

Implementation Details Training details: Pre-trained OFA-Large model (472M) Mix all the instances for all tasks. Each instance is randomly combined with one of its five instruction templates. Testing details: For each task, we conduct a total of five experiments by evaluating the model using one of the five instructions in each experiment. We report the mean and maximum performance and the standard deviation of the performance across all five experiments.

### Training details: - **Pre-trained OFA-Large model (472M)** - Mix all the instances for all tasks. - Each instance is randomly combined with one of its five instruction templates.
### Testing details: - For each task, we conduct a total of five experiments by evaluating the model using one of the five instructions in each experiment. - We report the mean and maximum performance and the standard deviation of the performance across all five experiments.

The image shows a slide from a presentation titled "Evaluation Metrics." The background is black with white text, and there are four bullet points detailing different evaluation metrics for various tasks. Here's the content of each bullet point:
1. For multi-modal classification tasks (Visual Entailment, Visual Spatial Reasoning, Natural Language Visual Reasoning, and Disaster Type Classification), we report the Accuracy. 2. For multi-modal generation tasks (Commonsense VQA, Text VQA, Grounded VQA, Visual Text Extraction, and Visual Dialogue), we report the Rouge-L. 3. For NLP tasks, we report Rouge-L. 4. We also compute the aggregated performance for each model based on the mean of the model‚Äôs performance on all multimodal and NLP unseen tasks. We use Rouge-L as the performance score for most tasks, and Accuracy only has accuracy as a metric.

Effect of Fine-tuning Strategies on Model Sensitivity Instruction tuning on Multilinstruct can significantly reduce the sensitivity of OFA.
